title: Computable isomorphism
summary: In computability theory two sets A ; B ⊆ N {\displaystyle A;B\subseteq \mathbb {N} } of natural numbers are computably isomorphic or recursively isomorphic if there exists a total bijective computable function f : N → N {\displaystyle f\colon \mathbb {N} \to \mathbb {N} } with f ( A ) = B {\displaystyle f(A)=B} . By the Myhill isomorphism theorem,[1] the relation of computable isomorphism coincides with the relation of mutual one-one reducibility.
